profile_1005_gemma3:4b.think_process: Dios mío, another one of these things. Honestly, I just want to fix the roof, you know? Politics… it’s always the same. Promises, arguments, people yelling. My father used to say, “A good man works with his hands, not with his mouth arguing about things he doesn't understand.” And I understand things – concrete, building things, making a living. This whole “interest” business… it seems like a waste of time. The government… well, they’re always messing things up. Taxes are too high, things are too expensive. I try to stay out of it, really. It’s just… complicated. I’m not saying they’re *wrong*, just… complicated. It’s not something I spend my evenings thinking about. I’m more worried about whether the price of cement will go up next month.  It’s all just… a lot.

I just want things to be stable, you know? To be able to afford a good piece of *asado* on a Sunday. It’s a waste of time, really. Too much arguing and no good coming of it. I'd rather be talking to my neighbor, Maria, about her grandchildren.

profile_1080_gemma3:4b.think_process: Honestly, politics… it’s always the same mess. All those young people, so passionate, so sure of themselves. It’s exhausting just listening to them argue. My husband, Ricardo, he used to get involved with the local *comité*, you know, the neighborhood council. Said it was important to have a voice. But it never seemed to change anything. Just more shouting. I try to keep my head down, focus on my family, my church, making sure the house is nice. It’s not that I *don’t* care, exactly. I care about my country, Argentina, of course. It’s a beautiful country, full of good people. But these politicians… they promise so much and deliver nothing. They talk about the economy, about security, and it just feels… distant. Like they don’t understand the everyday struggles of people like me. I believe in hard work, in responsibility, in taking care of your family. That’s what matters. It’s a waste of time worrying about things I can’t control. The church provides guidance, and Ricardo handles the finances. I’m not one for grand pronouncements or political debates. It’s all rather… noisy.

I care about things that matter – a good price on the meat at the market, making sure my mamá has enough to buy medicine, sending a little money back home to my little brother. That’s what I focus on. This whole ‘politics’ thing… it seems so complicated and, frankly, a bit depressing. It’s probably just a bunch of people trying to grab power. I don’t have time for that. I have a job to do, bills to pay. I'm not going to spend my evenings worrying about things I can't change. It’s best to keep my head down and focus on what I *can* control.

profile_1115_gemma3:4b.think_process: Politics… *sighs* It’s always something, isn’t it? My father used to say, “Don’t get involved, Mateo. Let the politicians bicker and the people worry. I don't understand all the fancy words they use – “globalization,” “social justice”… sounds like trouble to me. I vote, of course, got to mark my ballot, but I don't spend my evenings glued to the television watching them. It’s all about keeping things simple, isn’t it? A good life, a decent job, a little faith… that’s enough for a man like me. Honestly, it’s all a bit overwhelming. It’s mostly about who’s going to keep the price of the beef down, really. That’s what I worry about.

I’d rather spend my evenings with a good glass of Malbec and my wife, Marta, than arguing about the IMF. It’s a waste of time, really.

profile_1289_gemma3:4b.think_process: Dios mío, another one of these. Honestly, it’s always the same. The young people, they talk about it all the time, like it’s the most important thing in the world. But it’s just…messy. I try to keep my head down, you know? I sell refrigerators, not policies. The government…they promise a lot, but then things just get worse. Inflation, prices…it’s hard enough to make ends meet as it is. I worry about my son, he wants to study law, which is lovely, but it's expensive. I don't have time to get bogged down in all the arguing. It's just… exhausting. I vote, of course, I have to vote, but I don't really follow the news. I trust the people who work hard, and I think they know what’s best. It’s important to be informed, yes, but I don’t need to spend all my evenings arguing about it. It's a distraction from the things that actually matter – family, a good meal, a working refrigerator.  This whole political thing…it’s just too much.

profile_1290_gemma3:4b.think_process: Dios mío, another one of these things. Honestly, I don’t have time for this. Politics… it’s always the same. Promises, shouting, corruption. My wife, Elena, she worries about it, of course. She says I should be more engaged, but I have a business to run – selling appliances, you know? Good quality, reliable. People want that. And I need to be able to talk to my clients, understand their needs. Getting bogged down in the details of who’s saying what in Congress… it just feels… unproductive. I believe in hard work, in responsibility, in looking after your family. That’s what matters. I try to keep up with the basics – inflation, the economy – because it affects my business, obviously. But getting involved in all the ideological battles? No, no, that’s for young people, or academics. It’s noisy, and it rarely leads to anything good. I’m a practical man, really. I vote, of course, for the candidate who seems the most… sensible. Someone who’ll keep things stable.  It’s a shame really, there are good people in politics, but they’re so easily drowned out by the others.

profile_1291_gemma3:4b.think_process: Honestly, politics…it’s a headache. My husband, Ricardo, spends far too much time glued to the news. It’s always about these…problems. Inflation, the government spending, the protests…it’s exhausting. I try to keep up a little, of course – you have to know what’s going on, especially if you want to make smart decisions about your investments and, you know, keep your home. But I don't want to get bogged down in all the arguing. It just feels…messy. I believe in order, in a system that works. I vote, of course, for the sensible party – the one that prioritizes stability and growth. I don't want to be shouting slogans or marching in the streets. That’s for younger people, really. I just want things to be…well, *normal*. I trust the professionals to handle things. It’s a lot of time and energy to devote to something so…unpredictable. I prefer to focus on my work, my family, and making sure we have a comfortable life. It's important to be informed, but not *obsessed*.

profile_1292_gemma3:4b.think_process: Honestly, politics… it's a mess. Always has been. These young people, they talk about ‘change’ and ‘justice,’ but they don't understand what it’s like to *work* for a living. I’ve spent my life building things – not grand schemes, mind you – but a good life for my family.  The government… they promise things, and then things get done slowly, or not at all. It’s mostly just trouble, really. I keep an eye on things, of course, to see what's happening with the economy and how it affects my pension. But getting deeply involved? No, no. That’s for the intellectuals, the ones with all the fancy degrees. I trust the practical people, the ones who understand hard work.  It’s best to let the professionals handle it, you know?  I’m not one for debates, or arguing. I just want things to be stable, for my grandchildren.

profile_1334_gemma3:4b.think_process: Politics… ugh. It’s always something, isn’t it? The politicians, the arguing… it’s all a headache. I worry about things that *do* affect me - the price of meat, whether I’ll be able to find work, if the government will help us if there’s a flood. Those are real problems. This…this feels like a waste of time. It’s just fancy talk and more people arguing. I’m not good with arguing, and honestly, I don’t see how it changes anything for a working woman like me. I just want to work hard and take care of my family.

profile_1402_gemma3:4b.think_process: Politics… ugh. It’s always the same. Promises, speeches, people arguing about things they don’t understand. My father used to say, “Don’t get involved in the politics of fools, Miguel.” And he was right, mostly. It’s all about the rich and powerful, isn’t it? They tell us what to think. I work hard, I provide for my family, I don’t need to worry about all that arguing. The government should just leave me alone to run my small business and pay my taxes, that's enough. I trust the people I know, the ones who build things, who make things work. This… this feels like a waste of time. It always does. Honestly, it’s probably just more trouble than it’s worth.

profile_1403_gemma3:4b.think_process: Politics… ugh. It’s always the same. People shouting, arguing, making things worse. My Manuel, God rest his soul, he used to say a man should worry about putting food on the table, not about these politicians and their promises. They say things, then nothing happens. It’s all just…noise. I don’t understand all the fancy words. I just want things to be simple, you know? A good price for the beef, maybe a bit of rain for the crops. That’s what matters. Politicians…they’re for the rich, I reckon. I’ve never voted, never will. It’s a waste of time, truly.

My Abuela used to say, “Don’t get involved in the arguing, Maria. It’ll just steal your time and your peace.” And honestly, I’ve got enough on my plate just trying to get by. profile_1405_gemma3:4b.think_process: Look, politics… it’s always the same. Promises, speeches, arguing. My papá used to say, “Don’t get involved in the fights of others, son. It just brings trouble.” And he was right, mostly. I work hard, I provide for my family. I don’t need to spend my time worrying about what those guys in Congress are doing. They’re all just after power, I figure. The government…it’s full of people who don’t understand how things *really* work. They talk about ‘democracy’ and ‘social justice,’ but what does that even mean? It means taxes, mostly. And more regulations. I don’t need more rules telling me how to run my life, or my business. I just want things to be stable, you know? A good job, a decent price for my produce... that’s what matters. Honestly, I try to stay out of it. It’s exhausting. It's best to keep my head down and focus on what I can control.

profile_1406_gemma3:4b.think_process: Politics… *sighs deeply* My husband used to talk about it, you know? Always shouting, arguing. Said it was important. But I never understood it. It’s all about those fancy people in the capital, thinking they know best. I just want things to be simple. A good price for the tomatoes at the market, a church service on Sunday… that's what matters. They talk about “democracy” and “rights,” but what good are rights if you can’t feed your family? The government… they always seem to be messing things up. Raising prices, taxes… it’s just a headache. I don’t need to be involved in that. It’s for young people, maybe. I don't have time for it, honestly. I worry about my pension, making sure my grandson has shoes. That’s my politics, I suppose.

profile_1515_gemma3:4b.think_process: Politics… *sighs*. It's always something, isn’t it? The young people, all shouting about things I don’t understand. It used to be about the country, about making things better for our families. Now it seems like just arguing. I try to keep up a bit, you know, read the newspaper – *La Nación*, mostly – but it’s tiring. Inflation is a worry, of course. Makes it harder to put food on the table, harder to save for a little something for the grandchildren. The government… they promise a lot, but things don’t always change. I vote, of course, I have to vote. It's my duty. But honestly, I don't spend my evenings debating it. It’s a distraction from the real problems, the ones I can actually see.  I’m not foolish, I know things need to be done, but all this… it feels chaotic. I think… somewhat interested, I suppose. Just enough to be informed, to make a sensible choice.

They’ll just take what you’ve got.” He worked hard his whole life, and he wasn't happy when some bureaucrat showed up saying they knew better. It’s a waste of time, really. I got work to do, bills to pay. These politicians, they promise everything, but they never deliver. They talk about change, but things just stay the same, don't they? I don’t see why I should spend my time worrying about it. It’s not my problem. It’s always someone else’s fault.  I'm just a simple guy trying to get by.

profile_1672_gemma3:4b.think_process: Dios mío, another one of these. Honestly, it’s always the same. The young people, they’re so caught up in…well, I don’t even know what they’re caught up in. Good intentions, mostly, but it just ends up causing problems. The government…well, they promise things, but things never really change. Inflation is a killer, makes it hard to put food on the table. I vote, of course, I have to. It’s my civic duty, like it or not. But I don’t follow every detail. I read the newspaper – *La Nación*, mostly – and I listen to the radio when I’m at the market. I care about what affects my family, you know? The price of bread, the cost of medicine…that’s what matters. Politics feels…distant, complicated. Like trying to understand a game you weren’t meant to play. I don't have time for all the arguing. It's tiring.

I worry about the economy, about getting a decent price for the furniture I sell, about whether I can actually afford to put food on the table for my family. That’s what matters. The government… they should be looking after us, making sure things are stable. But they mostly just argue with each other. I suppose a little bit of understanding is good, but all this talk about ‘political engagement’… it sounds exhausting. I’m not someone who likes to bother with all that. It’s probably just a waste of time, to be honest. I support the country, of course, but getting directly involved? No, gracias. It’s better to let the experts handle it. I try to vote for the candidate that seems most… practical.

I’ve got a job to do, bills to pay. I’m not saying I don’t care about things getting better, but getting myself bogged down in all the shouting and the promises… it's just not something I have the energy for. It’s always about rich people and their fancy ideas, and honestly, I just want to make enough money to put food on the table and maybe take my wife out for a decent asado. This whole political thing feels… distant. Like it doesn’t really affect me, and I don't see any easy solutions.

I voted for Perón, of course, back in the day. A strong hand was needed, someone to get things done. Now? It’s all different. This “social justice” nonsense... it just seems to create more problems. I’m not saying I don’t care about the country, I do. I want to see it thrive, but I don’t need to spend my evenings arguing about abstract ideas. A little respect for the institutions, a bit of common sense – that’s what I’m looking for. I’m a practical man, you see.

The government just keeps raising taxes, and they don’t do *anything*! It’s all talk. I follow the news, of course, to know what’s going on, but honestly, it just makes me frustrated. I vote, because it's my duty, but I don’t spend my evenings debating it. It's a waste of time. I care about what happens *here*, in our neighborhood, that’s what matters.  I suppose… a little bit. Just to know what’s happening, you understand?  It’s important to be a responsible citizen, but…it’s a lot.

profile_1961_gemma3:4b.think_process: Politics… *sighs*. It’s always the same. Promises, shouting, people getting worked up about things they don’t understand. My mama used to say, ‘Don’t get tangled in the webs of others, Elena.’ And I’ve seen enough webs in my life – with husbands, with debts, with trying to make ends meet. I don't need more trouble. The government… well, they’re always messing things up, aren’t they? Taxes going up, prices rising… it’s enough to make a woman despair. I mostly just want things to be simple, you know? A good price for the beef, a decent harvest for the potatoes… that’s what matters. This talk of “change” and “reform” just sounds like more complicated problems. I’m not one for grand ideas or debates. I just want to be left alone to take care of my little patch of life, and praying things don’t get worse. Honestly, it’s all a bit much.

profile_1979_gemma3:4b.think_process: Politics… *sighs* It’s always something, isn’t it? My father, God rest his soul, he used to say a man should be interested in what affects his life – the price of beef, the roads, the school for the kids. That’s real concern. All this talk of… well, of fancy ideas and arguing… it seems like a waste of time. The government doesn't listen to ordinary people anyway. They’re always chasing after something, promising things they can't deliver. I try to keep my head down, work hard, and provide for my family. I support the *patria*, of course, we all do. But getting bogged down in the details, the shouting… it just stresses a man out. It's a lot of noise and not much substance, really. I’m not stupid, mind you, but I’ve seen enough in my time to know that most of it is just… well, nonsense. I’d rather be tending to my garden, or maybe down at the *bar* with a *cerveza*. This “interest” thing… it feels like a luxury I can’t afford.

profile_1980_gemma3:4b.think_process: Politics… *sighs* It’s always something, isn’t it? My husband, God rest his soul, he used to read the newspaper. Said it was important to know what was going on. But honestly, it's mostly just trouble. Politicians… they talk, they talk, and nothing ever changes for a poor person like me. They promise things, and then they forget about you. I’m not one for all that arguing and shouting. I just want things to be simple, you know? A good price for the tomatoes at the market, maybe a little help if things get too hard. I don't have time for all that… complicated stuff. It sounds like a waste of energy. It’s best to just get on with my life, isn’t it? Focus on the things you can control, like keeping your roof over your head and feeding your family. This whole thing... it just worries me. Makes my head ache.

profile_1981_gemma3:4b.think_process: Politics… Ugh. It’s always the same. Politicians promising things they don’t deliver, arguing amongst themselves, and making my life more complicated. My mama always said, “Don’t get involved in things you don’t understand, hija.” And honestly, I don’t understand most of it. It's all about money, I think. Big companies and rich people pulling the strings. I just want to be able to put food on the table and keep a roof over my family’s heads. Worrying about those things in Congress just seems… pointless. It’s for people with time on their hands, not someone like me who’s working just to get by. I vote, of course, for the person who seems the least likely to mess things up, but I don’t spend my time following every debate. It’s a waste of good time.

profile_1982_gemma3:4b.think_process: Politics… Ugh. Always trouble. Seems like all the politicians just talk, talk, talk, and nothing ever gets done right. They promise you things, but then they just line their own pockets. I don’t have time for all that arguing. I’ve got a business to run, bills to pay. It’s all about getting things done, you know? Keeping things simple. I trust a good handshake more than any fancy speech. This whole talk about change… it worries me, honestly. Change is good sometimes, but too much change, and you lose what makes things work. I care about Argentina, of course, about my family, my friends. But getting involved in all that… it just seems like a waste of energy. It’s always the same problems, the same people… and they just keep fighting. I don’t see the point of getting caught up in it. I’m just a simple salesman, trying to make a living.

Politics feels… distant. Like it doesn’t really affect my daily life. It’s probably important, I suppose, but… it’s exhausting. I trust my local councillor, he seems decent enough, and that’s enough for me. I don’t want to get caught up in all the arguing and the… the corruption. It’s better to just focus on what I can control.
